awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
The better understanding of granular matter, a class of materials comprised of large numbers of particles that collide and aggregate, is important for a wide range of industrial processes as well as natural phenomena, including the very beginning of planet formation from interstellar dust. The project introduces a new experimental platform, in which small particles are levitated acoustically, their arrangement can be manipulated under computer control, and their interactions can be measured with precision. The detailed investigation of such interactions among particles addresses many fundamental problems in physics and materials science, and improved knowledge about aggregate formation opens new opportunities for better control of industrial processes that involve the handling of fine particles. The project trains one graduate student, one postdoctoral scholar, and several undergraduate students, introduces them to forefront issues in materials research, and involves them in science outreach activities. 

Technical Abstract:
The project focuses on sub-millimeter scale particles, which can easily become charged and as a result exhibit a rich interplay of short-range contact forces and longer-ranged electrostatic forces. To measure these forces with precision while providing a means for controlled particle manipulation, ultrasonic levitation generates a stable environment in which gravity is balanced by acoustic pressure so that minute particle-particle interactions become observable. A special aspect is the implementation of a sound pressure field that can be changed in real time under computer control. This enables experiments that previously have not been possible, such as the measurement of charge transfer during repeated particle-particle collisions. Suitable acoustic potentials also can produce lattices of particles of the same charge polarity, similar to Coulomb crystals in dusty plasmas. Importantly, ensembles of macroscopic particles are easily driven into the strongly interacting regime, where the interaction potential far exceeds the ambient thermal energy. Two thrusts of the project develop a programmable acoustic cavity for multi-particle trapping and manipulation, and investigate the collective behavior of systems comprised of large numbers of levitated particles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The better understanding of granular matter, a class of materials comprised of large numbers of particles that collide and aggregate, is important for a wide range of industrial processes as well as natural phenomena, including the very beginning of planet formation from interstellar dust. We introduced a new experimental platform, in which small particles are levitated acoustically, their arrangement can be manipulated under computer control, and their interactions can be measured with precision. The detailed investigation of such interactions among particles addresses many fundamental problems in physics and materials science, and improved knowledge about aggregate formation opens new opportunities for better control of industrial processes that involve the handling of fine particles. 

The project focused on the use of acoustic levitation to investigate two types of granular interactions. First, we designed experiments to probe the origin of contact charging between granular materials. Contact electrification of small particles forms the basis for a myriad of physical phenomena. Some of these can be detrimental, such as the sticking of small particles to powder processing equipment or space suits, or the electric discharges and lightning generated by dust storms; others are beneficial, such as enabling small, interstellar dust agglomerates in the vicinity of stars to grow beyond the size of pebbles and, eventually, become planets. However, even the basic aspects of collisional charging between non-metallic particles are still debated. Our new experimental method, based on acoustic levitation, is the first to controllably collide two sub-millimeter particles repeatedly and measure the evolution of their electric charge one collision at a time, all with complete electric isolation the surroundings.  This ability to directly and noninvasively collide particles of different constituent materials, chemical functionality, size, and shape opens the door to detailed studies of collisional charging across a wide range of different granular materials.

Secondly, we used the acoustic scattering forces induced between particles as a general model of granular clustering. Clusters with small numbers of constituents undergo transitions and property changes not observed in bulk materials. When non-equilibrium forces are imposed on such clusters, the probabilities of such transitions can be influenced. Understanding how to control transition pathways broadens our understanding of how to create novel metastable states of matter. We found that the fluctuation statistics of the acoustic forces impacts the relative likelihoods of different cluster configurations. Our findings have consequences for the control of granular assemblies and also serve as models to explore and manipulate similar transition pathways in small molecules or nano-clusters of atoms.

Acoustic levitation can also be used to rotate objects rapidly.  We found that levitated particle assemblies, such as monolayer sheets or rafts of particles, can be spun up to the point of large deformation and break-up, highly reminiscent of how spinning liquid drops change shape and break up.  Because individual particles can be tracked with high-speed video, our results provide direct insight into how materials behave when stressed to the point of failure.  In contrast to liquids, which the constituent molecules held together by fixed surface tension, we found that the binding energy of constituent particles in acoustically levitated rafts increases with raft size. This is similar to fast-spinning objects held together by gravitational forces, such as so-called rubble pile asteroids. As such, we can view acoustically levitated, rapidly spinning particle assemblies as tabletop asteroids, where astrophysical processes that take millions of years, and occur on the scale of kilometers, can be observed and controlled in minutes in the laboratory.

The project trained one postdoctoral scholar, five graduate students, and three undergraduate students in forefront research in physics and materials science, preparing them for future roles as leaders in their scientific communities.
